meanings.definition: A person or thing that spoils or impairs something.
meanings.sent1: The vitiators of the picnic were the rain clouds that ruined the outdoor fun.
meanings.sent2: The vitiators of the garden were the pesky rabbits that ate all the vegetables.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel acted as a vitiator by stealing all the nuts from the bird feeder.
meanings.sent4: The weeds in the flower bed were the silent vitiators, slowly choking the vibrant blooms.
meanings.sent5: The broken swing set stood as a vitiator of the playground, waiting to be fixed.

meanings.definition: To make faulty or defective; impair or spoil.
meanings.sent1: Careless handling can vitiators the delicate glassware, causing it to break easily.
meanings.sent2: Leaving the milk out too long can vitiators its freshness, making it sour.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous puppy tried to vitiators the new shoes by chewing on them.
meanings.sent4: The storm's strong winds vitiators the roof, causing leaks to appear.
meanings.sent5: The lack of maintenance will slowly vitiators the car's engine, leading to costly repairs.

meanings.sent1: Failure to sign the contract properly can vitiators the agreement, rendering it invalid.
meanings.sent2: An error in the document could vitiators the entire legal process, causing delays.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick was to vitiators the audience's expectations, leaving them amazed.
meanings.sent4: The sudden change in weather vitiators our plans for a picnic in the park.
meanings.sent5: A single mistake can vitiators all the hard work put into the project, so attention to detail is crucial.
